THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1907.

div.head: A RESULT OF THE CRISIS.
div.p: One of the most awkward results of the acute financial crisis prevailing in Egypt is the stoppage of all offers for the new quay lands. Some critics assert that the Alexandria Municipality is partly to be blamed for having encouraged speculation by permitting payments for the quay lands to be made on the instalment system, thus permitting of speculators with but little capital making offers for the land with the intention of selling it at enhanced profits, and now these persons cannot pay up. Now all the sales have come to a complete standstill and the Municipality does not know which way to turn for money. It had been calculated that the Municipality would have been able to sell the lands at a fair prices and the proceeds would have gone on the great drainage works and the expropriations necessary for opening up certain insanitary quarters of the city. Bat all hopes of disposing of the land have to be abandoned for some time to come, for nobody knows when the "reprise," which we all long for so eagerly, will arrive. The consequence is that the Municipality finds itself with a large and highly paid staff of engineers, whose services were engaged for carrying out the proposed drainage scheme, but unfortunately there is no money to go on with this important enterprise, for all the cash in hand in the municipal coffers is already earmarked. The administrator of the Municipality therefore proposes to draw on the account current up to say L.E. 1,000,000. The Municipality would pay in the amount coming in from the sale of lands in order to wipe it off. All expenditure drawn from this sum would be controlled by the Government, which would have the power of vetoing any expense. It is considered that such a scheme would be far better than a loan, as there is no need to spend all the money at once and if a loan was raised, which could only be managed with the consent of the Powers, a great deal of the money would lie idle In the report on the municipal budget for 1908 the administrator alludes to the project in the following words :-

"Je proposerais dans ce but. l'ouverture d'une avance en compte courant de 1.000.000 de L.E. apprès de la calgae de la Dette Publique ou d'une ou de plusieurs banques de notre Ville avec la garantie du Gouvernement, ou auprès du Gouvernement loi-même, assuré par l'affectation des terrains du Quai. Cette opération' de trésorerie aura l'avantage sur un emprunt de ne pas immobiliser des fonds mais de nous procurer l'argent au fur et à mesure de nos besoins, diminuant ainsi les intérêts que la Ville sera appelée à payer aux créanciers........ "La somme de 1 million ne sera naturellement pas affectée dans une seule, année, et il sera toujours possible à la Commission, si la crise continuait et si l'avenir ne s'éclaircissait pas, de s'abstenir d'engager d'autres dépenses et de | limiter le debit de la Municipalité au chiffre répondant aux besoins les plus stricts. Il est à présumer du reste que les travaux auxquels les sommes seront consacrées exigeront plusieurs années pour être complétés et étant donné les rentrées qu'entre temps la Municipalité effectuera an moyen de la vente de ses terrains, le montant du debit n'absorbera jamais une somme considérable du compte ouvert. Au cas où cette combinaison ne rous. sirait pas, il faudra de toute façon rechercher les moyens de pouvoir augmenter les facultés d'emprunt de la Municipalite."

It is not believed that the Government will countenanoe the scheme, but as it is absolutely necessary to go on with the drainage of the city, it is essential that money should be found in some way or other.

div.head: The National Bank.
div.p: Mr. Sidney Bray, sub-manager of the National Bank, Khartoum, has resigned his position, and has been appointed agent of the Minieh branch of the National Bank in Egypt. Mr. Bray and Mrs. Bray left. Khartoum last week via the Port Sudan route last week,

div.head: Kamel Pasha's Health.
div.p: We regret to hear that the health of Mustapha Pasha Kamel at the present mouggnt leaves a great deal to be desired, and it is not improbable that his physical condition may prevent him from taking an active participation in political life.

div.head: Shepheards Hotel.
div.p: The next small dance will be given at Shepheards on Saturday and afterwards small dances will be held every Tuesday, The Christmas free entertainment is to be held at Shepheard's on Tuesday 24th inst. at 5 p.m. and the "Grand Ball" will. be given on Tuesday 28th January. The Fancy Dress Ball at the Casino, Ghezireh, will be given on Shrove Tuesday.

div.head: Engtish Companies in Egypt.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary published a telegram from London, dated the 7th inst., to the effect that the Foreign Office was on the point of asking Sir Eldon Gorst to study the situation of liability companies in Egypt registered under the companies Acts. We are in a position to state that the British Agency is quite unaware of any snch intention on the part of the Foreign Office.

div.head: Purification of Exyptian Railways.
div.p: The Egyptian Government Railways has accepted the tender of the Clayton Gas Company of Egypt and the Sudan for the purification of their rolling stock by means of this well-known process. Suitable gaslight sheds are now being erected at Cairo for the systematic disinfection of the railway carriages. This important new process will afford a great security to the travelling public. Moreover it will be a considerable saving of expense to the Egyptian Railway Administration as it will prevent the destructjon of their fittings by moth and dust.

div.head: "The Sphinx".
div.p: We welcome the first number of the fifteenth yolume of our ever popular Cairo weekly season contemporary the "Sphinx", which appears in better form than ever Under the editorship and managership of Mr. H. W. Hewlett there is no doubt but that this journal will continue in its path of steady progress and enhance the popularity which it has gained. It's contents are diverse—social, sporting, wit and humour, fashions for ladies, military notes, billiard notes, motor-car fotes, short stories by well-known authors, financial notes from London, local impressions, lists of those staying at the hotels of Lower and Upper Egypt and the Sudan, information for visitors to the. country, ete ete: The illustrations which the journal contains are most excellent and will be thoroughly appreciated by its readers, the nambers of whom increase year by year. Prominént among those of the number under review are photographs of Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst, Major General Bullock, C. B., and his staff, the funeral procession of the late Princess Hanern, King Edward's Birthday review, and some excellent views of Phile.

div.head: AN EXTRAORDINARY RUMOUR.
div.p: London, Monday.

An extraordinary rumour is published by the "Echode Paris" in a telegram from Toulon which states that great activity is being dispalyed in the arsenal due to the grave news recieved by the French Government in regard to the situation between America and Japan. On the other hand, Mr. Taft, speaking at Berlin, said that the relations between America and Japan were excellent and that it was quite erroneos to suppose that America had any intention of disturbing the peace.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Judgement was given yesterday evening in the case of Montano v. the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited, The Court rose at 6 p.m and judgment was given at 6.45 p.m. after the jury had deliberated for three quarters of an hour. The Court found for the plaintiff ons amount £1706 0s. 6d. and costs. The Anglo-Egyptian Bank had admitted liability with the defence and had paid £200 as sufficient damages to meet the ease. The jury was composed of Messrs. Perey W. Carver, Frank Hasleden, Captain Samuel Fawcett, Henry Thomas and Henry Hanley. Owing to the length of time this case has taken these gentlemen have been excused from sérving on a jury for three years.

The Supreme Consular Court did not sit to-day. The following cases are dowh for hearing in the undermentioned dates : Wednesday, 11th inst., Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt, Appeal Cases ; 11th and 12th Carasso v. Carasso, 13th inst , Estate of Balzan, application by Dr Rizzo-at 11.30 am. 14th inst. Barker's Estate. 16th inst. Canton murder case.

div.head: THE INTERNATIONAL CRECHE.
div.p: The Intertational Créche which was opened in Alexandria on June 17th, has fully shown that it serves a much felt want among the poorer classes of the population, for from that date until the 30th ulto, there was a total of 2110 attendances by 120. different children. These include 46 Syrian, 36 Greeks, 17 Italian, 14 Arabs, 4 Maltese, and 3 Cop's The average attendance is about 23 daily. This is the only institution. of the kind in Alexandria where childrenare taken by the day. The créche at the Maternity Home takes babies entirely ander its charge and the Greek community has a créche for foundlings, bat the interna tional eréche is specially for children, whose mother sare At work during the day. Of the mothérs of the childreen regularly attending this institation 6 are washerwomen, <7 dressmakers, 2 or 3 in domestic service, 2 hatmakers, while the others take in sewing at home. The children have three meals a day, inéluding an excellent midday meal and are bathed every morning. In October the numbers of children in attendance during the whole month totalled 562, which was the largest number that has been attained. Since then the bad weather las diminished the attendance but even now it barely falls below 20° The present Aéad-quarters of the oréche are at El Fabrizi street, near the Bab el-Ghedid Terminlus. It is intended to remove it to another house in the Bab Sidra quarter, which will be more convenient for the parents being nest the industrial part of the city and will have the advantage of a garden. The health of the children has been generally excellent

It is sincerly to be hoped that this excellent institution will not be allowed to suffer through lack of funds. Contributions, however small, will also be welcome and any stall offering will be gratefully accepted, all cash donations sent to the Secretary, Ismall Sedley Bey, at the Alexandria Municipality.

div.head:
MILITARY COURT OF INQUIRY:

div.p: London, Monday. It is reported that the military. Court of on Inquiry at Chelsea Barracks on the conclusion of its investigations into the case of Lieutenant Woods, of the 2nd Grenadier Guards, recommended that Lieutenant Woods should send in his papers. It is understood that he will decline to comply with at the recommendation and, moreover, intends to bring civil action Against three officers of his regiment.
(Gazette's Special Service.)

London, Tuesday, The Army Council memorandum on the Lt. Woods enquiry states that he is inefficient as a regimental officer and that the retention of his services is not in the interests of the Army. His superior officers were not actuated by prejudice in making their reports

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND RAMLEH AMATEUR MUSICAL AND DARMATIC SOCIETY.
div.p: A goodly company assembled yesterday afternoon at the Rudolph Home for the purpose of forming an amateur musical and dramatic society in Alexandria. Upon the proposal of Mr. J. Pearce-Hill, seconded by Mr. A Moss, Mr. W.T. Smith took the chair. The proposals of the promoters of the society were then put before the meeting by Mr. G.I. Swanson, and after discussion the following rules were adopted :-
The Society shall be known as the Alexandria and Ramleh Amateur Musical and Dracmatic Society.

The object of the Society shall be to promote amateur musical and dramatic entertainments and performances, the profits accruing from which shall be distributed among the various local charitable institutions according to the decision of the Committee, always provided that a surplus fand be retained for the payment of the expenses of the Society.
Election to membership of the Society shall be by application to a member of the Committee, and the applicant shall be notified by the Honorary Secretary of election.

Election to membership of the Society shall be by application to a member of the Committee, and the applicant shall be notified by the Honorary Secretary of election. Membership shall be either "individual" or "family." Individual members shall pay an annual subscription of P.T. 40 and the subscription" for a "family" membership, which shall be limited to four members of a family living under the same roof and shall exclude male adults, shall be P.T. 100.
The Committee shall have full power to decide upon those entertainments and performances to which members of the Society shall be admitted free.
The Committee shall consist of a President, two or more Vice-Presidents, seven Members of Committee, a Director and Stage Manager, a Treasurer, and a Secretary.
The Committee shall have power to add to its numbers and to elect sub-committees for any special object either from the Committee or from the general body of members.
The Committee shall have full power to decide what entertainments and performances shall be given, to fix the dates thereof and prices of admission and to distribute the surplus funds of the Society.
The accounts of the Society shall be audited annually and submitted to a general meeting of the Society.
A general meeting may be summoned at a week's notice by the Committee or on accepttance by the Committee of a request signed by not less than seven members of the society.
Twenty-one members shall constitute a gen- Ieral meeting
Five members of Committee shall constitute a quorum of Committee.

All who are willing to join the Society as constituted under the rules formulated by yesterday's meeting are requested to send in their names to the Honorary Secretary, c/o the "Egyptian Gazette" without delay.
The first concert will be held not later than in the first week of the New Year.

div.head: THE NEW DIRECTOR GENERAL
div.p: Captain Russell Robinson, who succeeds Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield as Director General of the Ports and Lights Administration, was only seconded from the Royal Navy on the 2nd inst. when he gave up his command Of H.M.S. "Africa", Channel Fleet, at Chatham. He is a relative of Mrs. Gedge who has been staying with Mrs. Robinson in West Kens- ington. On the arrival of Captain Robinson he will probably be the guest of Captain Gedge at his residence in the Arsenal.

div.head: TRIAL OF OFFICIALS.
div.p: Hafez Gobran, in the witness box, said that when any employé sought transferment of applicant eleotion, Spiro Bey would ask him how much he would pay. He said that he paid the balance of the £60, promised by him for his promotion to chief store-keeper, to Attiah Effendi George in 1906 and that on reading a Government circular prohibiting the payment of baksheesh he wrote to Attiah Effendi requesting the return of £54, but received no reply He also asserted be offered Spiro Bey a Credit Foncier Share and other shares, but these were refused. Dr. Jacovidis on being called said that he was taught Arabic by Hafez Gobran, who used to ask him for money on account to pay the bribes demanded.

At 4 p.m. yesterday the Advocate Wissa Boctor began his defence of Attia George, who was transferred to the Finance Ministry and had excellent certificates from his chiefs espécially from Talamaz Bey. He also pointed out that Admiral Sir M. Blomfield had recommended Attia for promotion in 1907.

The Chief of Parquet then proceeded to show how Attia had falsified documents and spread corruption in the Administration and proved how he and Spiro Bey arranged together to receive bribes, etc. He asked the court to punish them severely as an example to others.

The Court rose at 6 p.m. and reassembled at 7 p.m. to hear the case against Spiro Bey, Attia Effendi George, Kapondan Safwat, and Massalam Suleiman, who were collectively accused with receiving. L.E. 40, and butter, fowls, dates, etc.

The Chief of the Parquet showed how Safwat and Mossalam Suleiman tried by all means to get L.E. 40 as a bribe from Ismail Hassan, who was formerly Mamogrof the Rosetta Ports and Lights, and to give the money to Spiro Bey in order to promote Ismail to the first class of employés, and that Safwat kept L.E. 10 of the L.E. 40 for himself besides 5 tins of butter for Spiro Bey and a number of chickens and baskets of dates.
Safwat confessed that he received these articles, but he paid for them with the exception of the 5 tins of butter, which he sent to Spiro Bey, but he denied receiving the LE 40.
Bey, but he denied receiving the LE 40. The Chief of the Parquet reiterated the proofs of the charges and also declared that Attia had received LE. 2 for himself.
The Court rose at 9 p.m.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limitsfree discussion.

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir.--Your correspondent "Lex" in his letter published in your issue of Saturday raises a point which is of far more importance to holders of shares in companies registered under the English Companies Acts than they yet realize. The grave disadvantage of compary directors of foreign nationality not being responsible for breaches of the Companies Acts is, to my mind, considerably aggravated by the fact that in the vast majority of cases their employés and secretary are equally ignorant of the requirements and formalities of the Acts under which they work. Should any of these companies be forced into liquidation, or litigation be involved owing to the failure of others, there will doubtless be many unpleasant surprises awaiting the unfortunate investor.

To name a few of the instances in which trouble is bound to arise. Some companies have been mortgaging their properties without registering the deeds at the Companies Registration Office in spite of the stringency of the Acts on this subject. Calls have been and are being made not in accordance with the articles. Transfers not in order are accepted and passed, Shares are improperly cancelled after forfeiture and re-issued. New Directors are improperly appointed. Apparently the officials of some companies have not even read an elementary text book on company management nor had sufficient sense to employ a properly qualified solicitor to advise them.
Yours faithfully,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S STREETS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,--Cannot the Alexandria City Police do something towards clearing the streets in the heart of the European quarter of the City from the class of person, who in the evening throng the neighbourhood of the Ramleh Boulevard, Cleopatra street, etc. Last night I was escorting a lady friend from my house to her home and was appalled at what I not only saw but heard. The police seemed to regard the spectacle as a joke and seemed to be on quite friendly terms with the parties.
Truly Yours,

div.head: INFLUX OR VISITORS.
div.p: During the past few days quite a number of visitors have passed through here, some being old residents while others were paying their first visit. Inbuch a small community, villtors, whether strangers or otherwise are always welcome, even for the sake of seeing a fresh face or adding one more to the circle at the club, where their latest stock of yarns will receive full appreciation. Among our recent visitors may be mentioned Major Ravenscroft, Repression of Slavery Dept, who only returned to Khartoum the other day after a stay extending nearly three weeks, occupied in inspection and other work connected with this part of the Department, and also Captain Fielden, Senior Inspector, Port Sudan. Mr. Somerville of the Veterinary Department returned from a visit of Inspection extending as far south as the Eretrean Frontier. It is very satisfactory to note that the entire district was found to be free from cattle plague. By train on the evening of the 29th ult. there was quite an influx of visitors including Major Coutts, Inspector of prisons from Khartoum on Inspection Duty, and Bimbashi Fouth, Camel Corps, for purchase of camels, Mr. J. F. Luard, Manager Khartoum Branch, Bank of Egypt and Mrs: Luard, Mr. Job, Inspector of the National Bank. Major Coutts, and Mr. and Mrs. Luard returned to Khartoum again in the evening of the 29th ult.

div.head: Rifle Club Meeting
div.p: Friday the 28th ult. was quite a red letter day. On this date the opening of the range of the Red Sea Railway Rifle Club took place at Graham's point. In response to the invitation of the members of the club to an "at home," quite a large gathering assembled at 3 pm. when the first shot was fired by El Miralai C, J. Hawker Bey, Governor of the Province; with a well directed shot he placed the bullet on the bull's-eye.

The next event was an Open Sweepstake Competition, Entrance P. T. 10. "Stakes to be divided into 3 prizes. Conditions 200yards and 500yard, 7 rounds at each distance. Sighting shot optional, Bisley targets and scoring. Club rifles only to be used. The following are the scores :
There was a strong cross wind blowing which made high scoring almost impossible. Reid was declared the winter, having made a better score at the longer distance.
Shooting was begun at the 500 yards range, competitors and spectators then moved on to the 200 yards ranger where tea and refreshments were dispensed in a large marquee.
Darkness came on almost before the finish of the first competition and the other event on the programme--a team competition--had to be postponed.

In the absence of Major Hawker, who had to leave before the finish, the prizes were presented by Major Coutts, who congratulated the members of the club on their excellent range. A vote of thanks was passed to Bimbashi Russell for undertaking the marking, and carrying it out so efficiently Mr. R. Fawkes acted as range officer, and kept the scores to the satisfaction of all.

The thanks of the community are due to Bimbashi Russell for forming the club, which though ostensibly for the Railway Employés, admits other residents as honorary members. The range is quite up to date in every particular, with telephonic communication, revolving targets, etc. Fridays are the practice days.

div.head: Red Sea Railway.
div.p: On the 30th ult, the S.S. "Wensleydale" from London arrived with a very large consignment of goods and material, chiefly for the Railway, and it is expected she will take a week to ten days discharging. There are a number of passengers on board mostly bound for Mombassa.

div.head: Queen's Birthday Parade.
div.p: On the 1st inst. the birthday of Her Majesty the Queen, the troops stationed here were paraded in the early morning, and inspected by the Governor, while at noon a Royal salute was fired.

div.head: The Protestant Church
div.p: The Rev. H.B. Rivington arrived on Saturday the 30th Nov. and conducted Divine Service in the Mudiria on Sunday at 6.30 p.m.
There was a very fair attendance, which would undoubtedly have been greatly augmented but for the wet and stormy weather.
A general meeting of the church members was held in the mudiria on Monday evening, at which a Church Committee was elected. and other business transacted.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Don Carlos is arriving in Cairo next January. The Duke and Duchess of Madrid have reserved a beautiful suite at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo.

The Duke and Duchess of Aosta left Cairo yesterday, after a week's stay at the Savoy Hotel The Duke of Aosta, is returning to Europe tomorrow by the North German Lloyd's S.S. "Schleswig", and will disembark at Naples.

The Duchess has gone to the Sudan where she intends to spend the whole winter owing to her chest troubles which regularitated her leaving Europe immediately after attending the Bourbon marriage in England.

To-morrow Prince Nousretus Sultana Nassireddin Nurza, the brother of the Shah Persia, and his mother and a large suite are arriving at Port Said from Constantinople by the Khedivial Company's S.S. "Tantah". They are on their way to Mecca and will disembark at Jeddah.
The Earl and Countess of Sefton are expected at the Savoy Hotel to-day.
Marquis de Fioravanti and Baron Viellan fangue are staying at the Savoy Hotel Cairo.

Sir Eldon Gorst will visit the Sadan this winter, accompanied by, Sir William Garstin, adviser to the Ministry of Public Work s. They Will probably leave Cairo on the 28th of December, and after a few days stay in the Sudan, will return to Egypt with Mr. Winston Churchill.
Princess Bonapatte has disembarked at Piraeus. The King and the Royal Family went to meet her. The Mayors of Pirseus and Athéns read addresses and the people warmly welcomed her. (Havas)

The Chamber of Deputies sitting on Sunday adopted the budget: The Socialist, M. Car- nand, brought in an amendment raising the tax on speculative bourse transactions,in spite of the opposition of the Minister of Finance, who while agreeing to the principle, opposed the increase at the present time of monetary crisis as tending to cause a panic on the Paris market. ( Reuter)
There is an unconfirmed report that Dini Zulu surrendered yesterday.
(Later). The surrender of Dini Zulu is con- firmed. A conveyance has been sent to fetch him. (Reuter)
A serious situation has arisen in the gold fields district of Nevada owing to an extensive strike, the miners objecting to payment by cheques
The strikers destroyed the railway by dyna mite for the purpose of blowing up the troops sent from here.
A catastrophe was only averted by the vigi- lance of a special gang of trackwalkers.( Reuter )

div.head:
A CALIFORNIA TRUST
COMPANY.
THREE DIRECTORS ARRESTED.

div.p: Three directors of the California Safe De- posit Trost Company have been arrested on the charge of misappropriation of fund. It is ae- certained that the Company's liabilities amount to 9,000,000 dollars and its assets to 4,000,000 dollars. (Reuter)
The King will take the title of Gustav V. The funeral of the late King will take place in a fortnight. ( Reuter)
The German Emperor has terminated his visit to High Cliffe and retarned here. He is in excellent health, He lunched with King Edward and King Haakon at Buckingham.
(Reuter )

The special Abyssinian mission, under the presidency of General Dedjaz Mechecha, has returned to Constantinople. The Mission was received last Friday after the Selamlik ceremony in private audience by the Sultan. In the course of the andience General Mechecha remitted to his Majesty a letter signed by Negua Menelik in which the Emperor thanks the Sultan for the welcome given to the mission on its last visit to Constantinople and expresses the hope that a friendly solution will be arrived at concerning the possession by the Abyssinians of the convent at Jerusalem known as Deir Sultan, at present held by the Copts- Until now the Mission bas only been able: to obtain a half support, by the division of the keys between the two parties. General Mechecha hopes to obtain the. exclusive rights. In ten days he will leave for Abyssinia via Jerusalem.

div.head: MAIDEN VOYAGE OF THE "HELIOPOLIS"
div.p: London, December 2.

The magnificent steamer "Heliopolis," of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, com- menced her first voyage on November 28, when she left her moorings at Greenock to proceed to Plymouth, en route for Marseilles. The strong westerly yale of the previous day had moderated, and the ship started on her tripdown the Firth of Clyde under the most favourable auspices. In addition to the pas- sengers for Egypt who had selected to set out from Scotland, there was a goodly number of experts in maritime matters, who proceeded as far as Plymouth, in order to personally test and experience the sea-going qualities of the ship. Among the large company on board were the Chairman, Lord Armstrong, and Mr. Q. T. Symons, Managing Director of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company ; Mr. A. 8. Williams, manager of the Royal Mail Steam- ship Company; Mr. J.8. Inglis, general ma- nager of the Great Western Railway and others.

The. "Heliopolis" and her sister ship, the "Cairo," are both built by the Fairfield Shipbuilding Company, of Glasgow, and are not only tur- bine driven but propelled by triple screws, all working by turbine: mechanism, the engine horse-power being 18,000 and the ship's ton- nage 12,000 gross. The most noticeable feature with regard to this use of the turbine system is the absence of vibration and the noise ine- vitably associated more or less with the. old reciprocating-engine arrangements, and in this, as in every other respect, the vessel must be pronounces a complete success. Although dur ing aportion ofthe voyage a speed wasobtained of 22 knots, in most parts of the ship the fact of her being in rapid motion was hardly perceptible, and, indeed, the mental effect was so slight that the passengers wondered whether the vessel had not temporarily ceased "going ahead."

Some particulars of the magnificent equip- ment of the "Heliopolis" -were published by us on the occasion of the launch, but now that all the interior arrangements and the elaborate decorations are complete, for which Mr. F. W Collinson is responsible, a far better idea of her splendour and comfort can be obtained. The idea which has been so successfully achiev- ed, was to construct a vessel in which every- thing should be sithordinated to the require- menta of passengers. Ibe considerations, there fore, as to the conveyance of cargo have been kept in the back-ground.

Some idea of the dimensions of the "Helio- polis" may be formed when it is explained that there are in all seven decks, apon five of which, at léast, large state-rooms and numerous ele- gant saloons are arranged. Abaft the officers quarters upon the upper deck is a café designed in Regency style in panelled oak. Below this, upon what is termed the promenade deck, is the Jarge deck-house, and in this, as also on the deck below, are a series of magnificent saloons, only equalled by the reception rooms of a first-class modern hotel.

The saloon upon the promenade deck is arranged as a 'insic room, and is 45 feet by 30, most charmingly furnished in Louis Quinze style, finighed in white. Upon the bridge deck are the library decorated in Regence style, and the smoking room, 50 feet, by 40 exeellently ventilated. Upon the stage below is the magnifi- cent dining saloon, capable of seating some 260 persons at one time. Jt is fitted with tables of various sizes, to accomodate both large and small parties of travellers. From personal experience during the voyage, we can unhesita- tingly assert that the cuisine could not be surpassed. The food is of the finest quality, and the chefs employed are masters of the culinary art. As there are so. many stages and decks, a lift has been provided for the convenience of passen- gers, and everything that can conduce to their comfort in the way of electric lighting, ventilating fans, eté. even including electric curling tongs, in the cabins have been provided. Great care must have been exercised, arid advice of responsible experts obtained, in the selection of the library, for not only have the choicest works of modern fiction and travel been chosen, but others of a more erudite character upon Egyptological subjects, besides such books of history as may be said to possess an interna- tivnal reputation, are generously provided. We cordially wish the Egyptian Mail. Steamship Company the success to which their enterprise entitles them, especially when it is realised that they are offering the public a service that is unique in more ways than one. Not only do

The "Heliopolis" with about 400 passen- gers on board left Marseilles for Alexandria on Saturday afternoon, and is due at this latter port this afternoon. Passengers will most probably arrive in Cairo by spec- ial train this evening at 8.25 p.m. On Thursday there will be an inaugural lun- cheon on board. A special train will bring the guests from Cairo at 8.15 a.m. on that day arriving at Gabtary Quays at 11.40 a.m. On the return journey the train will leave the quays at 5 p.m., reaching Cairo at 8.25 p.m.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH
div.p: "Fiscal" writes to "The Times" saying:-
You reported Lord Cromer as having stated that during the whole course of the occupation the principles of free trade have been rigidly ap- plied in Egypt."

May I ask him to explain how it is that in the Estimstes for 1907 £1,800,000 figures as revenue from customs—this sum being over 12 per cent. of the entire estimated revenue and nearly 4 per cent. on the entire imports and exports of merchandise
Is it not afact that there is a 1 percent. ad talorem duty on all exports from Egypt and a 4 per cent. ad valorem daty on all im- ports into Egypt.

I am, of course, familiar with the possible answer that these duties are levied for revenue and not for protective, purposes; but I would snggest that, while no one would advocate even a 4 per cent. ad valorem daty on all im- ports into the United Kingdom, such a pro- posal might be defended on exactly the same grounds and would, I am sure, be, notwith- standing, vigorously denounced as rank protec- tion by all the gentlemen with whom Lord Cromer associates himself.

Out of the 24 millions imports into Egypt I find that over three millions are "cereals and vegetables." It would be interesting to know whether this duty on food is 4 per cent or 8 Tobacco figures as an import for nearly, £700,000. Has not the growing of tobacco been prohibited in Egypt, and is this a rigid application of free-trade principles

Post entries will be accepted but it is desirable that names of competitors be called for and submitted as soon as convenient to this office by Officers Commanding Units.

div.head: A VETERAN OF THE 1885 NILE EXPEDITION
div.p: Mr. P. Creedon, 17, Slattery's Lane, Black- pool, Cork, Ireland, is an Army Pensioner, having served for over nine years in India and having taken part in 1885 in the Nile Expedi- tion. When he retired he was Sergeant Major of the Durham Light Infantry.

He made a most interesting statement to one of our representatives, saying: "Two years ago I had a most dangerous attack of influenza which left me a martyr to rheumatism. Later on severe pains struck me across the kidneys, stabbing pains that seized me at all times and which made it most difficult for me to straight- en myself after stooping. My rest—that is to say, the little I obtained-left me tired and exhausted in the mornings. The kidneys acted badly, the secretions being disordered. My eyes were puffed up and I had frequent attacks of dizziness, especially after stooping, when I used to feel that I should fall if I did not catch hold of something to support me. Pain in the region of the heart often troubled me. Then my ankles and feet swelled at times, and altogether I was in a very bad condition.

"The doctor attended me, but his medicine did me little or no good. Last April, however, I learned about Doan's Backache Kidney Pills and decided to get some of them. I took them, but at first noticed no material improvement; I bought a second box and then a third, and by this time there was no mistaking the good they were doing me—the kidney secretions were free and without pain, the pains in my back were gone, and I felt a different man in every way. (Signed) P. CREEDON."

Just upon three years afterwards, Mr. Creedon wrote to say: "Since being cured by Doan's Backache Kidney Pills I have never had a return of the old complaint. I always recommended them in simple gratitude for the benefit I derived from them."

Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 18 P.T. per box, or 71.P.T. for 6 boxes ; or they may be had direct from the agents for Egypt, Mr. E. div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
